artists.name: Roy Lichtenstein
artists.biography: Lichtenstein then left New York to study at Ohio State University, which offered studio courses and a degree in fine arts. His studies were interrupted by a three-year stint in the Army during and after World War II between 1943 and 1946. After being in training programs for languages, engineering, and pilot training, all of which were cancelled, he served as an orderly, draftsman, and artist.

paintings.title: Brushstroke with Spatter
paintings.description: a wry commentary on the bravura of midcentury Abstract Expressionism. Here Lichtenstein combines the gestural sweep of Willem de Kooning’s brushwork with the rhythmic drips typical of Jackson Pollock. He isolates and magnifies his stroke and spatter against a ground of Ben Day dots, reproducing the conventionally painterly elements as flatly as possible with no trace of emotion or texture.

paintings.title: Foot Medication
paintings.description: While he had adapted his early compositions from actual comic books, here Lichtenstein rather referred to an art historical rather than a pop culture source: Henri Matisse’s Red Studio (1911; Museum of Modern Art, New York), which features Matisse’s canvases casually set around a room.

paintings.title: Alka Seltzer
paintings.description: The artist’s use of mechanical reproduction conventions served to unify his composition and produce movement and volume on a two-dimensional surface. Alka Seltzer is one of Lichtenstein’s watershed works because it shows the artist summing up his early graphic techniques and introducing what would become his most significant formal preoccupations in the years that followed

paintings.title: Woman III
paintings.description: In Woman III Lichtenstein injected both humor and a Pop Art chill into the older painter’s wriggling swaths and slashes of bold color while playing directly on de Kooning’s series of confrontational “Woman” paintings. The fierce figure is denoted by two eyes, an elfin ear, nose, lips, bared teeth, and a patch of red dots that stand in for a rouged cheek.

paintings.title: Landscape 4, from Ten Landscapes
paintings.description: Lichtenstein exploited everyday practices of visual representation and magnified them, indicating the gas bubbles rising over the glass by meticulously scraping away extra spaces from a field of imitation hand-stenciled Benday dots

artists.name: Andy Warhol
artists.biography: No artist is more closely associated with advertising, consumer culture, and mass media than Andy Warhol. Through his brazen appropriation of images and his radical use of the photo-emulsion silkscreen process, the artist became synonymous with Pop. His ability to produce the same image—over and over, quickly and efficiently—upset traditional boundaries between fine and commercial art.

paintings.title: Marilyn Monroe (Marilyn)
paintings.description: Marilyn was the first such portfolio, consisting of ten images made from the same 1953 publicity photograph of Marilyn Monroe in the film Niagara, which Warhol transformed with intentionally off-register printing and garish combinations of psychedelic colors.

paintings.title: Mao
paintings.description: The most influential of Pop artists, Andy Warhol cast a cool, ironic light on the pervasiveness of commercial culture and contemporary celebrity worship. Early in his career, he began to utilize the silk-screen process to transfer photographed images to canvas, creating multiple portraits of celebrities including Marilyn Monroe, Elvis Presley, and Jacqueline Kennedy, as well as duplicated images of mass-produced products such as Campbell’s soup cans and Coca-Cola bottles.

paintings.title: Early Colored Liz
paintings.description: Pop Art icon Andy Warhol’s embrace of mass culture radically altered the course of late twentieth-century art history, redefining both what a work of art can or should depict as well as the way in which it can be made. His breakthrough artistic moment came when he took the commercial printing process of photo-emulsion silkscreen and applied it to canvas.

paintings.title: Self-Portrait
paintings.description: Warhol based his first painted self-portrait on a photo booth photograph, and the work showcases Warhol’s ability to manipulate his persona itself as an artistic medium. As he admitted a few years later, “I’d prefer to remain a mystery, I never like to give my background and, anyway, I make it all up different every time I’m asked.” This work marked a starting point for Warhol’s career-long engagement with the construction of identity, especially as it pertained to crafting his public persona.

President John F. Kennedy. As was his practice, Warhol worked from existing imagery; in this case, press photography from the slain president’s funeral. By cropping and enlarging the selected image of the veiled former First Lady, Warhol focuses attention on his “star” much like a director using a close-up lens. The effect is a chilling glamorization of the tragic.

artists.name: Diego Rivera Barrientos
artists.biography: A leader of the Mexican muralist movement of the 1920s, who sought to challenge social and political iniquities, Diego Rivera often turned to indigenous themes to foster Mexican cultural pride. After years of rigorous art training in Mexico City, he traveled throughout Europe before settling in Paris in 1912, where he befriended other emigré avant-garde artists, including Amedeo Modigliani and Piet Mondrian.

paintings.title: Weaving
paintings.description: The woman, a well-known weaver, expert in the Nahuatl language, and popular artists’ model named Luz Jiménez, appears intently focused on creating the intricate red, blue, white, and black pattern of the fabric that is rolled up in her lap. Placed against the spare background of Rivera’s studio, the weaver’s actions take on greater significance and dignity.

paintings.title: Portrait of Marevna
paintings.description: Early in his career, Diego Rivera enjoyed a brief but sparkling period as a Cubist painter. After years of rigorous art training in Mexico City, he traveled throughout Europe from 1907 to 1910. In l9l2 Rivera settled in Paris, where he befriended other emigré avant-garde artists, such as Amedeo Modigliani and Piet Mondrian. During World War l, he became a leading member of a group of Cubists that included Albert Gleizes, Juan Gris, and Jean Metzinger.

paintings.title: Portrait of Florence Arquin
paintings.description: Sarasota, Ringling Museum of Art, Latin American Horizons, Apr 8May 16, 1979; Miami, Metropolitan Museum and Art Center, May 28Jun 30, 1979; Pensacola Art Center, Jul 15Aug 15, 1979; St. Petersburg, Museum of Fine Arts, Sep 1Oct 1, 1979; Fort Lauderdale Museum of the Arts, Nov 130, 1979.

paintings.title: Still Life with an Apple
paintings.description: Educated in Mexico City, Diego Rivera also studied art in Madrid and Paris. The simplified forms and juxtaposition of everyday objects in this carefully rendered still life reflect his encounter in Paris during the second decade of the 20th century with the emerging Cubist movement. This artistic foundation would ultimately contribute to the bold style he developed as a leader of the Mexican Mural Renaissance. Rivera’s Communist affiliations were a cause of friction for him in the United States, especially during the McCarthy era.

artists.name: Vincent Van Gogh
artists.biography: During Vincent van Gogh’s tumultuous career as a painter, he created a revolutionary style characterized by exaggerated forms, a vivid color palette, and loose, spontaneous handling of paint.

paintings.title: The Bedroom
paintings.description: In ﬂat tints, but coarsely brushed in full impasto, the walls pale lilac, the ﬂoor in a broken and faded red, the chairs and the bed chrome yellow, the pillows and the sheet very pale lemon green, the bedspread blood-red, the dressing-table orange, the washbasin blue, the window green. I had wished to express utter repose with all these very different tones.” Although the picture symbolized relaxation and peace to the artist, to our eyes the canvas seems to teem with nervous energy, instability, and turmoil, an effect heightened by the sharply receding perspective.

paintings.title: A Peasant Woman Digging in Front of Her Cottage
paintings.description: The artist; his mother, Mrs. A. C. Van Gogh Carbentus, Neunen and Breda, around 1885 [ according to a letter from Martha Op de Coul, Rijksbureau voor Kunsthistorische Documentatie, The Hague, Netherlands, Aug. 23, 2000]; given to the carpenter, Schrauwen, Breda, 1886 [this and the following according to Stokvis 1926, 5-6]; transferred to Jan and Rien Couvreur, Breda, 1903; sold to C. Mouwen, Jr., Breda; sold, Frederik Muller, Amsterdam, May 3, 1904, lot 13, for 205 fl. to Van Gelder [according to annotated copy of sale catalogue; in curatorial object file].

paintings.title: The Poet’s Garden
paintings.description: The artist’s sister-in-law, Johanna van Gogh-Bonger (died 1925) [see Nordenfalk 1946 and Supinen 1990]. Galerie d’Art Odenzeel, Rotterdam [La Faille 1928, 131]. Galerie d’Art d’Audretsch, The Hague, Netherlands [according to information on Registrar archival card, copy in curatorial object file]. M. Gieseler, The Hague, Netherlands, by 1925; Sale, A. Mak, Amsterdam, Oct. 1925, lot 33. Howard Young Galleries, New York [stock no. 2486, according to Registrar archival card]. Mrs. Lewis Larned (Annie Swan) Coburn (died 1932), Chicago, by at least 1928 [see Registrar receipt dated May 28, 1928, copy in curatorial object file]; bequeathed to the Art Institute, 1933.

artists.name: Katsushika Hokusai
artists.biography: Katsushika Hokusai’s woodblock print The Great Wave is one of the most famous and recognizable works of art in the world. This work is from Hokusai’s much-celebrated series Thirty-Six Views of Mount Fuji (Fugaku sanjûrokkei), a tour-de-force that established the popularity of landscape prints, which continues to this day. Hokusai spent the majority of his life in the capital of Edo, now Tokyo, and lived in a staggering 93 separate residences.

paintings.title: Shower Below the Summit
paintings.description: Katsushika Hokusai is considered one of the greatest artists in Japanese history, and one of the important masters of the Japanese woodblock print. Hokusai’s most famous work is the series Fugaku sanju-rokkei (Thirty-Six Views of Mount Fuji), created between 1830 and 1832, when the artist was over seventy years of age.

paintings.title: A Peasant Crossing a Bridge
paintings.description: An old peasant returns from gathering the two bundles of horsetail rushes, which hang from a pole across his shoulder. Of the various poems about gathering rushes in the old anthologies

paintings.title: Under the Wave off Kanagawa
paintings.description: Katsushika Hokusai’s much celebrated series, Thirty-Six Views of Mount Fuji (Fugaku sanjûrokkei), was begun in 1830, when the artist was 70 years old. This tour-de-force series established the popularity of landscape prints, which continues to this day. Perhaps most striking about the series is Hokusai’s copious use of the newly affordable Berlin blue pigment, featured in many of the compositions in the color for the sky and water.

artists.name: Jean Marc Janiaczyk Douai
artists.biography: Jean-Marc Janiaczyk was born in 1966 in Douai, in the north of France, he is a self-taught landscape painter who painted exclusively oil paintings and in 1990 he started with a technically demanding style, hyper-realism. In 1998 he began to use a spatula and devoted himself above all to landscapes of Provence, with their vibrant and intense colours. In his paintings he has faithfully portrayed the light and heat of the region's summer. Bright red poppies, orange sunflowers, fields, modest houses on the side of the road receding into the distance... in the author's landscapes one can see some similarities with the works of his teacher and inspirer, V. Van Gogh. He exhibited his works in Florida, France, Denmark, Germany, Spain and Morocco and his paintings are in many private collections in France, Belgium, USA, Denmark, Germany, Spain, Czech Republic and Morocco.

paintings.title: Lavender and Sunflowers in Provence
paintings.review: Lights up my entire home with its colors
paintings.description: Lavender is an essential plant of Provence, it is cultivated and distilled to obtain an oil, to be used mainly in cosmetics and perfumes. Under the sun's rays, lavender welcomes you by releasing its fragrance. Lavender fields are fascinating because of these colors that change depending on the light of day, blue, violet, pink, and even orange tones in the light of sunset.

paintings.title: Purple Sun
paintings.review: It's impressive how the artist captures every last detail
paintings.description: She knew that one day he would come with his purple flowers

paintings.title: Poppies
paintings.review: Can you imagine living in such a landscape? Jean makes it happen!
paintings.description: Oil painting of poppies and palette knife.

artists.name: Bav Jozwiak
artists.biography: Bav Jozwiak has earned his signature status with the American Watercolor Society, the National Watercolor Society, Watercolor West, and others too numerous to mention. She is an internationally awarded artist. Born in Vancouver, Washington, Bev still resides there with her husband of more than 30 years. He has two daughters and three grandchildren. She has been featured in countless Best of Art Books, including numerous times in North Light's popular Splash series. He has had a plethora of magazine articles, including an emagazine cover, the cover of Sept. 2017 of North Light Watercolor Magazine, and the cover of Palette magazine in 2019.

paintings.title: In the hood
paintings.review: It was love at first sight!
paintings.description: The watercolor painting stands out for its transparency, the clarity of its colors, and the spontaneity. The watercolor colors are obtained with pigments that are very finely ground and bound with gum arabic, it dissolves easily in water and adheres very well to paper. Painting with water-based pigments is one of the oldest techniques. During the Renaissance and later centuries, all preliminary studies, sketches, drawings and jottings in the open air were done with a gouache, mainly colored sepia. It is in the eighteenth century the most brilliant era of watercolor, painters of English romanticism raised this technique to its highest level.

paintings.title: It's a knot
paintings.description: The watercolor painting stands out for its transparency, the clarity of its colors, and the spontaneity. The watercolor colors are obtained with pigments that are very finely ground and bound with gum arabic, it dissolves easily in water and adheres very well to paper. Painting with water-based pigments is one of the oldest techniques. During the Renaissance and later centuries, all preliminary studies, sketches, drawings and jottings in the open air were done with a gouache, mainly colored sepia. It is in the eighteenth century the most brilliant era of watercolor, painters of English romanticism raised this technique to its highest level.

paintings.title: Raised and born in Seattle
paintings.description: The watercolor painting stands out for its transparency, the clarity of its colors, and the spontaneity. The watercolor colors are obtained with pigments that are very finely ground and bound with gum arabic, it dissolves easily in water and adheres very well to paper. Painting with water-based pigments is one of the oldest techniques. During the Renaissance and later centuries, all preliminary studies, sketches, drawings and jottings in the open air were done with a gouache, mainly colored sepia. It is in the eighteenth century the most brilliant era of watercolor, painters of English romanticism raised this technique to its highest level.

artists.name: Elena Kraft
artists.biography: Hello, my name is Elena, I am an artist and choreographer and I live in Kiel. I masterfully combine figurative, floral, portret and animal painting. In Kiel I own two dance schools and my artwork is inspired by my passion for dancing, merging the charm and grace of a dancer, thus giving the paintings a very special, very sensual touch. Furthermore, through years of experience with body control, as well as the insight of an expert in body language, which I acquired in the long years as a trainer, choreographer and dancer, I bring my paintings to life in a very artistic way. When I finish a painting, I am ready for it to find its new home. I've had my time creating and developing, and when it's over, my time with it is over and I know it was created for someone else's enjoyment. I love what I do. I love creating works of art and I am proud of the images I create. Beautiful and meaningful images that speak to people as much as they spoke to me.

paintings.title: Awakening
paintings.description: Acrylic paint is a class of paint that contains a plasticized material, quick-drying paint, in which the pigments are contained in an emulsion of an acrylic polymer. Although soluble in water, once they dry they are resistant It stands out especially for the speed of drying. Likewise, when it dries, the tone changes slightly, more than in oil. Acrylic paint dates from the first half of the 20th century, and was developed in parallel in Italy and the United States

paintings.title: Winds of Summer
paintings.review: Take me right back to my childhood
paintings.description: Acrylic paint is a class of paint that contains a plasticized material, quick-drying paint, in which the pigments are contained in an emulsion of an acrylic polymer. Although soluble in water, once they dry they are resistant It stands out especially for the speed of drying. Likewise, when it dries, the tone changes slightly, more than in oil. Acrylic paint dates from the first half of the 20th century, and was developed in parallel in Italy and the United States

paintings.title: Behind schemes
paintings.description: Acrylic paint is a class of paint that contains a plasticized material, quick-drying paint, in which the pigments are contained in an emulsion of an acrylic polymer. Although soluble in water, once they dry they are resistant It stands out especially for the speed of drying. Likewise, when it dries, the tone changes slightly, more than in oil. Acrylic paint dates from the first half of the 20th century, and was developed in parallel in Italy and the United States

artists.name: Kate Louise Powell
artists.biography: Kate Louise Powell is an illustrator and animal rights activist from Halifax, West Yorkshire, currently based in Glasgow. After drawing recreationally all her life, Kate began to take her art career more seriously in 2012, producing a series of popular illustrations featuring the recurring motifs of flowers and butterflies. Since then he has experimented with photography, mixed media and painting, but continues to work primarily with colored pencil/pencil and black ink.

paintings.title: Frou-Frou Foxes
paintings.description: This was a real technical challenge for me, but I am very happy with the result and it was an absolute pleasure to spend so much time and energy on something so whimsical and full of the joy of life.

paintings.title: Anniversary for Freedom
paintings.description: Let's focus on who they really are, and how we can best help them while being compassionate to others.

paintings.title: Healing
paintings.review: I saw it and I knew it, thanks for existing Kate!
paintings.description: It's so hard to put into words: truly connecting and accepting myself, finding the ability to comb through and deal with the past, understanding how to live with certain truths instead of desperately hoping they'll go away, the relief and sense of growth that comes out of all of this. I've looked back at my old art and realized that years ago I tended to draw people in huddled positions with their backs to the world, I think unconsciously it was an expression of my vulnerability, insecurity, fear... While that I now feel so at ease and capable, a sense of being one with my own being that I have never experienced before. A kind of healing that feels like landing back in my own body after not being fully there for for as long as I can remember... The way I no longer feel suffocated and terrified is really unreal.

artists.name: Adilov Kabul
artists.biography: Adilov Kabul was born in 1959 in Tashkent, Uzbekistan. He studied art in St. Petersburg, Russia, and graduated from the St. Petersburg State Academy of Painting, Sculpture and Architecture in 1985. He moved to Budapest, Hungary in 1987. Despite his youth, he has been one of the most colorful personalities of Hungarian contemporary art. His talent is endowed with the mysterious charm of his native land, its rich historical and cultural legacy. The name chosen by Adilov Kabul, alias Chaghatay, evokes the surroundings of the old quarter of his father's house. In his landscapes the ancient and modern vision of the world are combined. In his figures myth and poetry are united. His rich art is inspired by the vision of the intimate unity of man and nature. His works are found on three continents of the world. He has exhibited in many of the former Soviet Union republics and later in Japan, India, South Korea, and Spain. His largest solo exhibition was held in Munich, Germany. mania, and the Ross Gallery exhibits his works constantly in London.

paintings.title: Viharos
paintings.description: Oil consists of mixing pigments with an oil-based binder, usually of vegetable origin. By extension, oil is called the pictorial work executed using this technique, which admits supports of a very varied nature: metal, wood, stone, ivory, although the most common is that it is applied on canvas or board. The oil remains wet for a long time, which favors the mixing of colors. Its drying can be compromised depending on the accessories that are put on it during the process, such as cobalt siccative, which can crack oil as it dries.

paintings.title: Terrace
paintings.description: Oil consists of mixing pigments with an oil-based binder, usually of vegetable origin. By extension, oil is called the pictorial work executed using this technique, which admits supports of a very varied nature: metal, wood, stone, ivory, although the most common is that it is applied on canvas or board. The oil remains wet for a long time, which favors the mixing of colors. Its drying can be compromised depending on the accessories that are put on it during the process, such as cobalt siccative, which can crack oil as it dries.

artists.name: Winslow Homer
artists.biography: Winslow Homer is known for his dynamic portrayals of the power and beauty of nature and his reflections on humanity's struggle with the sea. A keen observer of the world around him, Homer also experimented with color, form and composition, pushing his landscapes and genre pictures in modern directions.Raised in Massachusetts, he apprenticed in a Boston lithograph shop in the mid-1850s and soon found work as a freelance illustrator.Moving to New York, He did work for Harper's Weekly, among other magazines, and enrolled in drawing classes at the National Academy of Design.

paintings.title: Water Fan
paintings.description: The water fan depicts a young man searching intently for corals with a glass-bottomed bucket. This device, known as a water glass or sponge glass, was used to stabilize the surface of moving water with the to improve visibility. It is possible that Homer was attracted to the subject because the surface of the water in constant movement, as well as its transparency, attracts attention, aspects of the sea that intrigued him especially in the Bahamas.

paintings.title: Campfire, Adirondacks
paintings.description: In Campfire, Adirondacks, guide Rufus Wallace sits among the protective roots of an overturned giant hemlock. The roots of the tree are formally expressive elements in their own right, but these ancient tentacles also seem to protect the man at rest.
